The programme support to the International Social Science Council (ISSC) stands as a pioneering research-policy initiative aiming at increasing the social science contributions necessary to craft more effective, equitable and sustainable responses to the problems of climate, global environmental change and sustainable development.

The International Social Science Council (ISSC) established in 1952 by UNESCO representing the social, economic and behavioural sciences at an international level has launched a programme called "Transformations to Sustainability: A 10-year Social Science Research Funding and Coordination Programme on Global Change and Sustainability", i.e Transformation to Sustainability (T2S) programme. This programme aims at building a global transformative social science-led transdisciplinary research to sustainability.
ISSC has since merged with ICSU (June 2018) and is now the organisation ISC (International Science Council). The T2S programme remains, and aims at building a global transformative social science-led transdisciplinary research to sustainability. The programme is designed to form a T2S research community through a global call for which research teams are joined by researchers from the global north and south as well as low and lower-middle income countries. Sida support was first channelled 2014-2017, then extended to 2018-2021 (now 2022).
The T2S programme (2017-2022) has two major objectives: - To develop understanding of and promote research on transformations to sustainability which are of significant social, economic and policy concern throughout the world and of great relevance to both academics and stakeholders; - To build capacity, overcome fragmentation and have a lasting impact on both society and the research landscape by cultivating durable research collaboration across multiple borders, disciplinary boundaries, and with practitioners and societal partners. This includes facilitating the development of new research collaborations with parts of the world which are not often involved in large-scale international research efforts, notably low- and middle-income countries.
There are unique goals for the four-year extension of the programme: 1. To harness the knowledge, research results and networks created by the Transformative Knowledge Networks (TKNs), particularly in the period 20182019, to amplify the impact of the first set of projects;
2. To promote and facilitate the full and equal participation of researchers from the global south in the Belmont ForumNORFACE T2S progam over the period 2018-2021, and to integrate them into the wider T2S network through knowledge exchange and knowledge integration activities.
There are three Transformative Knowledge Networks (TKNs): 1) Acknowl-EJ; Acronym stands for Activist-Academic Co-Production of Knowledge Team - Environmental Justice; 2) Pathways; and 3) T-learning.T stands for transformative, transgressive and transdisciplinary.
Through the calls for researchers (see above), research teams have been formed clustered in the three networks, with the intention to chart new transformative pathways towards sustainability and ways of working. Critical dimensions include social justice, environment/climate, conflict and power relations.

description.narrative:
NORFACE and the Belmont Forum launched the T2S research programme in January 2017. After a joint Call 12 projects were selected for funding and started their work in 2018.
As a whole the T2S programme has performed well and reached its targets, or is on track to reach the targets. In 2020 and 2021, due to COVID-19 restrictions, most of the planned engagements had to change, either be postponed or shifted to a virtual format. ISC appears to have managed this shift very well, although there are significant delays in the programme. 2020 should have been a year of fieldwork and data collection for the 12 T2S projects. Due to the Covid pandemic 2020 instead became a year where many of the encounters had to be virtual and many activities were postponed. The projects managed to use information and communication technologies in creative ways to continue data collection and collaboration, although they confirmed that reaching the most marginalized and least connected communities was the greatest challenge during the pandemic. They also used the slowdown in activities to focus on reading, data analysis, writing, communication, training and personal capacity building. Several of them have been able to incorporate considerations relating to the Covid pandemic into their research.
The reporting for 2020 gives a very full picture of the achievement during the year despite the pandemic. There are many links to videos and articles that have been produced during the year and high-lights of the different projects are presented. The high-lights were provided between 18 and 24 months after completion of the projects, with a focus on impact in the community.
A follow-up survey of the Transformative Knowledge Networks (TKNs), was conducted between late 2020 and early 2021. The feedback and information from the three teams suggests that all three projects have made significant contributions to theory, methodology, policy, practice, research capacity and community-building. In the second half of 2020 a midterm evaluation of the T2S programme was conducted by a panel of four external experts. Regarding scientific quality, the panel considered that the programme was making good progress towards meeting scientific objectives at the project level, despite the pandemic. The panel found that the programme had made a substantial step towards increasing North-South collaboration in social science sustainability research. However, they identified a pattern of project leaders and Principal Investigators from Global North countries coordinating research in the Global South, which seemed to be a direct outcome of the programmes funding model. The panel found overall that the programme was being well implemented, and that the kickoff and mid-term events, organized by the ISC, were possibly the most important added value of the programme so far. The programme website, maintained by the ISC, was also identified by the panel as a particularly useful resource.
The T2S programme organised a conference in connection with the SRI conference in Brisbane, Australia, in June 2021 (Sustainability Research & Innovation Congress). The event was originally planned for June 2020 but was delayed for one year and held successfully online. The programme officer was able to attend and get a good understanding of the results achieved by the T2S supported programmes.
The European Commission approved a 12-month, no-cost extension of the programme until 31 December 2022 that allowed the projects to request no-cost extensions until 30 September 2022. All projects have requested extensions, of between three and nine months, which should allow them to achieve most of their original objectives. The agreement with Sida has been amended, with the activity period now ending 31 December 2022. The expenditure was significantly lower in 2020 and 2021 than planned. This was mainly due to the Covid pandemic which resulted in cancelled meetings and travel, and some cancelled/postponed activities. The Pathways Transformative Knowledge Network has underspend significantly. Some of these funds have been approved for use in 2021 and 2022. Due to delays in the execution of the programme a no-cost extension has been approved until December 2022. Some of the funds from the Pathways TKN will be used in 2022.
The CEO of the ISC from 2018 to 2022 has resigned. She has now joined the University of Pretoria, South Africa, as Interim Director of the Future Africa Institute. This is an interesting centre which might well figure in other collaborations that we are involved in on the continent. The Science Director is the acting CEO while they are recruiting a replacement.
